PAGE.TITLE: Integration by substitution
PAGE.DESCRIPTION:
When looking at the following problems remember that when using integration by substitution you must change three things; namely:
The limits if it is a definite integral.
The integrand
The infinitessimal (often $\textrm{d}x$)
When you look at the worked examples and at the problems start by trying to work out how these things have been done or how they should be done.

EXERCISE.TITLE: Exercise 1
EXERCISE.PROBLEMS: Find the following indefinite integral (hint: use the substitution $u=x-1$) $$ \int \frac{x^2 + 1}{x-1} \textrm{d}x $$

EXERCISE.TITLE: Exercise 2
EXERCISE.PROBLEMS: Find the following indefinite integral (hint: use the substitution $u=\sqrt{x+1}$) $$ \int \frac{x}{\sqrt{x+1}} \textrm{d}x $$

EXERCISE.TITLE: An exercise based on probability theory
EXERCISE.PROBLEMS: Suppose the continuous random variable, $X$, has the Cauchy probability distribution, defined by the probability density: $$ f_X(x) = \frac{a}{\pi(a^2 + x^2)} \qquad -\infty \lt x \lt + \infty $$ where, $a > 0$ is a constant. Use the substitution $x=a\tan t$ to verify that $\int_{-\infty}^\infty f_X(x) \textrm{d}x = 1$. Hint: remember that $1+\tan^2(t) = sec^2(t)$.
